posts.name: Murilo Miranda Santos
posts.cooked:
Good morning everyone! I’m a programmer on a relatively new FRC team that’s been around for almost three years. We recently had a meeting with a more experienced team from Brazil and realized that our programming style wasn’t keeping up with our development and wouldn’t meet our future goals. Currently, we’re trying to put each component of our robot as a subsystem and each action as a command, activating it in our container. So, I’m asking the Chief Delphi community for help, asking for the opinions of experienced programmers. So, if there’s anything I can improve, something wrong with the logic, or even some custom of your team that could help, please write a reply to this post. I appreciate your attention and help.

GitHub - muriloMiranda404/c-digo-para-atualiza-o- Contribute to muriloMiranda404/c-digo-para-atualiza-o- development by creating an account on GitHub.

Contribute to muriloMiranda404/c-digo-para-atualiza-o- development by creating an account on GitHub.

this is the link to repository

posts.name: Karl Olson
posts.cooked:
Overall it looks great, nice job!

Two things that might save you some confusion:

It would be typical to split IntakeCommand into two files called, for example, SetIntakeAlgaeSpeedCommand and SetIntakePositionCommand . It can be confusing to others who read your code that a simple 1 or 2 is the difference between what you are setting and also what motor you are changing the behavior of. Generally it’s good if one command does one clear action.

Try to be more descriptive with variable names. This will be useful if other members of your team need to modify your code or if others need to help you. In IntakeSubsystem , for example, the motors are called intake and algae . It might be better to call the first intakeMotor , or even better intakePivotMotor or intakeRollerMotor or similar (I don’t know what your robot looks like).

A small thing is that it looks like you are creating two instances of your intake and elevator subsystem, one in robot and another in robotContainer. I’m not too familiar with commands based, but I think you keep all your subsystem instances in robotContainer.

posts.name: Murilo Miranda Santos
posts.cooked: This is because there are things that we did in our old way of programming, but we couldn’t put them as commands, like resetting our elevator encoder in teleopInit(), rotating the elevator when placing it in L1, etc… So, we put them separately

posts.name: Karl Olson
posts.cooked:
To solve this issue, we put something like this in the ElevatorSubsystem

And use ElevatorSubsytem.getInstance() in Robot and RobotContainer . Then you can use it in both places but only one ElevatorSubsystem instance is ever created.

But I would suggest not doing this until you’ve thought deeply about if you really need the subsystems in both places. It may be dangerous or cause issues if you aren’t careful.

posts.name: Bryson Smith
posts.cooked:
Alternatively to olsonkarlp’s solution, you could have a function of the Robot Container to reset the elevator’s intake and call that in teleopInit. For example: RobotContainer.java

Then, in your Robot.java

As I mentioned in the comments, it would be best to do the same thing for your intake instead of constructing a second instance of it in Robot.java. If you want an example for this, too, I’d be happy to write it.

I wrote this on CD , so if the code formatting is a little off or if there is a typo in the code, I’m sorry.

posts.cooked: I changed it as you put it in your answer. Can you see if I changed it correctly?

posts.name: Karl Olson
posts.cooked:
You shouldn’t need a new in ElevatorSubsytem subsytem = new ElevatorSubsytem().getIntance(); .

Also,

As written, this will make a new elevator instance every time because you return the new subsystem without every setting elevator , so elevator will never be anything but null .

Because of these confusions, and possible problems depending on what you do inside Robot and RobotContainer ,

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
olsonkarlp:

Just for educational purposes for anyone reading this… this is called the “singleton” pattern and is very common in software engineering.  There are many other design patterns that serve different purposes.  This is a topic I highly recommend reading up on for anyone interested in computer science/software engineering as a career.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
There’s really no reason to use singletons in FRC ; the point of a singleton (compared to a simple global) is that you can override the getInstance implementation to do different things in different contexts (e.g. in a test suite).  If you’re not actually leveraging that flexibility, it is pointless boilerplate.

I don’t really like global subsystems in general, since they make it very easy to accidentally cause a confusing resource contention bug.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
My comment was simply to give the pattern a name, not to recommend for or against it.

Learning patterns is useful.  Part of learning them is learning when it is or isn’t appropriate to use each.
